content: so the idea here is to make an
understated piece of terrain that's extremely versatile in a couple
different ways it's also a pretty easy build works great in your D&D
role-playing game or you're working
we're going to be doing some mitered cuts with the proxxon table I've set it
at 35 degrees use a protractor to set the carrier along the yarn and then Mark
the arm with a sharpie so you know for the future what angle that position
corresponds to after that it's exactly the same as any other cut except you
might need to dial up the voltage a little bit since there's more surface
area cutting so from one-inch thick extruded polystyrene or home insulation
cut a square three and three-quarters of an inch and then miter two sides of it I
used 35 degrees make four of these pieces then cut a one and three quarter
inch square and again miter the two sides again make four of these then hot
glue each to the top of a larger piece like this
cut three squares each three and a half inches and hot glue them together in a
stack this is the center of the pyramid the last four pieces are a little tricky
you need to make this begin by cutting a standard rectangle five and a half
inches long and three and a half inches wide
then mitre one of the short ends at sixty degrees this will be the bottom of
the ramp and the other short end at thirty degrees this will become the
surface that attaches to the center and here it is being hot glued to the center
stack do all four
then hot glue the four corners in place making sure to glue to both adjacent
ramps for texture I did the rolled-up tinfoil ball
followed by brickwork with a pen as Jake from mini terrain domain tells us you
gotta earn this there is no shortcut for stonework from here you can paint it up
however you like and before we go to the table I'd like to take a moment to thank
all wcv sponsors this week I draw your attention to dungeon cast by Dan vicini
Dan's designs are full on custom resin casts he's currently focusing on one and
a quarter inch grid tiles destined for box sets with voluble DMD scenarios in
them basically an evening in a box so click the link in the description below
and check out the dungeon cast Facebook page so this was a simple black bomb
followed by a light gray overcoat to miss the cracks a white drybrushed
highlight and finally a black wash over the whole thing
now I didn't tie with the idea of carving the necrons symbol into each of
the four ramps which would have looked sweet could airbrush them to glow etc
but then the piece becomes typecast I could really only use it in one specific
setting this way it works for my D&D games my fantasy wargames or my sci-fi
wargames the top surface is big enough to house any MacGuffin that you like an
objective marker a treasure a magical doomsday device whatever and each of
these tiers allows for the placement of miniatures to give a mechanical or
tactical advantage
I am why lock thank you for joining me and I'll see you next time
